description: From Middle English rate, from Old French rate, from Medieval Latin rata, from Latin prō ratā parte (“according to a fixed part”), from ratus (“fixed”), from rērī (“think, deem, judge, estimate", originally "reckon, calculate”).

entries.meaning: (obsolete) The worth of something; value. [15th–19th centuries]
The proportional relationship between one amount, value etc. and another. [from 15th c.]
examples: At the height of his powers, he was producing pictures at the rate of four a year.

entries.meaning: Speed. [from 17th c.]
examples: The car was speeding down here at a hell of a rate.

entries.meaning: The relative speed of change or progress. [from 18th c.]
examples: The rate of production at the factory is skyrocketing.

entries.meaning: The price of (an individual) thing; cost. [from 16th c.]
examples: He asked quite a rate to take me to the airport.

entries.meaning: A set price or charge for all examples of a given case, commodity, service etc. [from 16th c.]
examples: Postal rates here are low.

entries.meaning: A wage calculated in relation to a unit of time.
examples: We pay an hourly rate of between $10 – $15 per hour depending on qualifications and experience.

entries.meaning: Any of various taxes, especially those levied by a local authority. [from 17th c.]
examples: I hardly have enough left every month to pay the rates.

entries.meaning: (nautical) A class into which ships were assigned based on condition, size etc.; by extension, rank.
examples: This textbook is first-rate.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) Established portion or measure; fixed allowance; ration.
(obsolete) Order; arrangement.
(obsolete) Ratification; approval.
examples: Tis offerd, Sir, 'boue the rate of CaesarIn other men, but in what I approueBeneath his merits: which I will not faileT'enforce at full to Pompey, nor forgetIn any time the gratitude of my seruice.

entries.meaning: (horology) The gain or loss of a timepiece in a unit of time.
examples: daily rate; hourly rate; etc.

verbs.description: rate (third-person singular simple present rates, present participle rating, simple past and past participle rated)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To assign or be assigned a particular rank or level.
examples: She is rated fourth in the country.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To evaluate or estimate the value of.
examples: They rate his talents highly.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To consider or regard.
examples: He rated this book brilliant.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To deserve; to be worth.
examples: The view here hardly rates a mention in the travel guide.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To determine the limits of safe functioning for a machine or electrical device.
examples: The transformer is rated at 10 watts.

entries.meaning: (transitive, chiefly Britain) To evaluate a property's value for the purposes of local taxation.
(transitive, informal) To like; to think highly of.
examples: The customers don't rate the new burgers.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To have position (in a certain class).
examples: She rates among the most excellent chefs in the world.
He rates as the best cyclist in the country.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To have value or standing.
examples: This last performance of hers didn't rate very high with the judges.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To ratify.
To ascertain the exact rate of the gain or loss of (a chronometer) as compared with true time.

description: From Middle English raten (“to scold, chide”), from Old Norse hrata (“to refuse, reject, slight, find fault with”), from Proto-Germanic *hratōną (“to sway, shake”), from Proto-Indo-European *krad- (“to swing”). Cognate with Swedish rata (“to reject, refuse, find fault, slight”), Norwegian rata (“to reject, cast aside”), Old English hratian (“to rush, hasten”).

verbs.description: rate (third-person singular simple present rates, present participle rating, simple past and past participle rated)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To berate, scold.
examples: Conscience is a check to beginners in sin, reclaiming them from it, and rating them for it.
